channel.title: Comments on: Developing a MEAN app with Angular 2.0
channel.description: Knowing is different & Doing is different

item.title: By: ravi
item.dc:creator: ravi
item.description: Uncaught ReferenceError: System is not defined

item.title: By: Andrè Driesel
item.dc:creator: Andrè Driesel
item.description: Getting this error: EXCEPTION: self.parent.context.deleteTodo is not a function is there any update needed?
item.content:encoded:
Getting this error:
EXCEPTION: self.parent.context.deleteTodo is not a function
is there any update needed?

item.title: By: Peter David Carter
item.dc:creator: Peter David Carter
item.description:
Should we really need Express.js given that Angular2 has built-in http, routing and rest functions? This seems more like an Angular1, MEAN stack approach applied to a technology that really shouldn't need so many intermediate stages -- stages which are likely to come at the cost of increased complexity, if not necessarily decreased performance or increased server load (that's going to depend on the exact implementation, of course...
I'm also concerned about how this setup might deal with observables, and if it will properly utilise their potential in the way we certainly should be if we are going to push web technology to the next level, and not be content with another 5, 10, 15 years of the same old functionality underneath the same old Twitter Bootstrap frontend.
So far I've only seen this tutorial and one for Postgres connected through Rails, both of which seem suboptimal solutions given the versatility and efficiencies that Angular2 has seemed to promise in its inception, and if we are to see a real competitor, if not outright replacement, to React, and to the in-browser VM technologies which seem as prevalent as ever.
item.content:encoded:
Should we really need Express.js given that Angular2 has built-in http, routing and rest functions? This seems more like an Angular1, MEAN stack approach applied to a technology that really shouldn’t need so many intermediate stages — stages which are likely to come at the cost of increased complexity, if not necessarily decreased performance or increased server load (that’s going to depend on the exact implementation, of course…

I’m also concerned about how this setup might deal with observables, and if it will properly utilise their potential in the way we certainly should be if we are going to push web technology to the next level, and not be content with another 5, 10, 15 years of the same old functionality underneath the same old Twitter Bootstrap frontend.

So far I’ve only seen this tutorial and one for Postgres connected through Rails, both of which seem suboptimal solutions given the versatility and efficiencies that Angular2 has seemed to promise in its inception, and if we are to see a real competitor, if not outright replacement, to React, and to the in-browser VM technologies which seem as prevalent as ever.

item.title: By: Ashish Gupta
item.dc:creator: Ashish Gupta
item.description:
Hi Arvind, I have one easy question, 1) are we rendering the page from server side as i have seen this video https://angularu.com/VideoSession/2015sf/angular-2-server-rendering ,for the better performance and easy loading.
2) If that so How to use preboot library . as the Angular2.0 its very responsive so we can render it from server side,if you have any idea please share. thank for your good totorial is very good .
item.content:encoded:
Hi Arvind,
I have one easy question,
1) are we rendering the page from server side as i have seen this video https://angularu.com/VideoSession/2015sf/angular-2-server-rendering ,for the better performance and easy loading.

2) If that so How to use preboot library .
as the Angular2.0 its very responsive so we can render it from server side,if you have any idea please share.
thank for your good totorial is very good .

item.title: By: Yaseen Llies Meridja
item.dc:creator: Yaseen Llies Meridja
item.description:
Thanks that's a great talk which I haven't seen yet. After making the comment above I went digging further and found the AngularConnect videos of last week, so I watched the keynote: https://youtu.be/UxjgUjVpe24
So in summary there are a few big projects that are already migrating to Angular2 and since I am starting on small greenfield project I thought, yeah what the heck why not give Angular2 a shot.
item.content:encoded:
Thanks that’s a great talk which I haven’t seen yet.
After making the comment above I went digging further and found the AngularConnect videos of last week, so I watched the keynote:
https://youtu.be/UxjgUjVpe24

So in summary there are a few big projects that are already migrating to Angular2 and since I am starting on small greenfield project I thought, yeah what the heck why not give Angular2 a shot.
